title: Understanding Rydberg's Equation
text: Rydberg's equation is used to calculate the wavelength of light emitted when an electron transitions between energy levels in a hydrogen atom. The formula is: $$\frac{1}{\lambda}=R_H \left(\frac{1}{{n_1}^2}-\frac{1}{{n_2}^2}\right)$$, where λ is the wavelength, $$R_H$$ is the Rydberg constant (1.097*10**7 m**-1), $$n_1$$ is the lower energy level, and $$n_2$$ is the higher energy level.

title: Identify the Energy Levels
text: For this problem, the electron transitions from $$n=3$$ to $$n=1$$. Identify the $$n_1$$ for the equation.

title: Identify the Energy Levels
text: For this problem, the electron transitions from $$n=3$$ to $$n=1$$. Identify the $$n_2$$ for the equation.

title: Substitute Values into Rydberg's Equation
text: Substitute the known values into Rydberg's equation: $$\frac{1}{\lambda}=1.097\times{10}^7 \left(\frac{1}{1^2}-\frac{1}{3^2}\right)$$.

title: Simplify the Equation
text: Simplify the expression inside the parentheses: $$1-\frac{1}{9}$$.

title: Calculate the Wavelength
text: Now calculate the wavelength using the simplified equation: $$\frac{1}{\lambda}=1.097\times{10}^7 \frac{8}{9}$$.

title: Convert to Nanometers
text: Convert the wavelength from meters to nanometers by multiplying by $${10}^9$$.
